1007012359263510528.text: I'm not going to say that it's *impossible* that this could be executed via a web browser or a similarly "quasi-remote" attack, but it's much harder than Meltdown was.

1007012140346060800.text: You need to be able to execute code on the same CPU as the target process in order to steal cryptographic keys this way.  You also need to perform a specific sequence of operations before the CPU pipeline completes, so there's a narrow window for execution.

1007011664300892160.text: The impact of this bug is disclosure of the contents of FPU/MMX/SSE/AVX registers.  This is very bad because AES encryption keys almost always end up in SSE registers.

1007011195998466048.text: This affects recent Intel CPUs.  It might affect non-Intel CPUs but I have no evidence of that.  It is an information leak caused by speculative execution, affecting operating systems which use "lazy FPU context switching".
